snippet: In a trend seen across Europe, Hungary has imposed taxes on salt, sugar and the ingredients in energy drinks, hoping to raise revenues and spur healthier eating habits.
abstract: Hungary has imposed taxes on salt, sugar and the ingredients in energy drinks in past 18 months hoping both to raise revenues and force those who are eating unhealthy foods to pay a little more toward the country’s underfinanced health system; taxation of unhealthy foods is something of trend across Europe, with many nations having either instituted such taxes or considered them.

byline.contributor: Michael M. Grynbaum contributed reporting from New York, and Gabriella Horn from Budapest.

lead_paragraph: In a trend seen across Europe, Hungary has imposed taxes on salt, sugar and the ingredients in energy drinks, hoping to raise revenues and spur healthier eating habits.

headline.seo: Hungary Experiments With Food Tax to Coax Healthier Habits
headline.main: Hungary Tries a Dash of Taxes to Promote Healthier Eating Habits
headline.print_headline: Hungary Tries a Dash of Taxes to Promote Healthier Eating Habits
